newsitem.title: USA: Magellan raised technology holdings in April.
newsitem.headline: Magellan raised technology holdings in April.

text.p: Fidelity Investments said its Magellan Fund raised its holdings in technology stocks to 14.4 percent of assets at the end of April from 13.7 percent at the end of March.

Magellan's holdings in energy shares slipped to 13.3 percent of assets at the end of April, the most recent date figures are available, from 14.0 percent at the end of March, according to Fidelity's monthly mutual fund guide.
Holdings in finance companies accounted for 11.4 percent of assets, up from 10.6 percent, and health care firms rose to 8.4 percent from 7.8 percent, the fund guide said.

Holdings in the industrial machinery and equipment sector slipped to 8.1 percent from 8.4 percent, durables dropped to 7.0 percent from 8.1 percent, and retail and wholesale stocks edged down to 6.6 percent from 6.7 percent.
In addition, portfolio manager Bob Stansky added non-durables to the portfolio and cut the fund's exposure to transportation stocks.
Non-durables accounted for 4.1 percent of assets at the end of April versus zero at the end of March and transportation stocks dropped to zero from 3.9 percent, the fund guide said.
The fund's top 10 holdings were largely unchanged, with Microsoft Corp added to the list and Chrysler Corp dropped.
Remaining in the top 10 were General Electric Co, Intel Corp, Philip Morris Cos Inc, Citicorp, Merck & Co Inc, CSX Corp, Schlumberger Ltd, Exxon Corp, and Home Depot Inc.

Magellan's asset allocation was also largely unchanged. Equities accounted for 95.9 percent of assets, down slightly from 96.4 percent at the end of March. Cash and other holdings rose to 4.0 percent from 3.5 percent, and convertibles were unchanged at 0.1 percent. Magellan had zero invested in bonds.
Foreign investments accounted for 9.1 percent of assets, down from 10.3 percent.
Magellan's total assets, propelled by strong returns during the month, rose to $56.26 billion at the end of May, up from $52.99 billion at the end of April.
